intro: Fimbristylis ferruginea var. anpinensis, commonly known as the red-haired sedge, is a flowering plant native to parts of Southeast Asia. It belongs to the Cyperaceae family, which includes sedges and related grass-like plants. The plant is characterized by its narrow, grass-like leaves and produces small, spike-like inflorescences. It typically grows in wetland or marshy environments, thriving in moist, nutrient-rich soils. Its botanical features make it an important component of wetland ecosystems.
